data.title: New jasmine spec runner concatenates nested describe strings, which makes them hard to read
data.body:
The old runner retained the structure of the describes when showing spec results in the runner. The new one merges them all into a single string, which is really hard to read with our style of nesting. It would be nice to hack in a better display for it.

![Screen Shot 2013-02-02 at 5 07 18 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1789/121428/b1abb4de-6d95-11e2-8f8c-e372e0a9c26b.png)

data.title: Make jQuery usable from a web worker
data.body:
This will require adding more properties to the fake `window` object and `self` object that the web worker shell sets up.

Currently it throws an error because of the missing `userAgent`.

data.title: Reusable styles for common UI elements
data.body:
WIP:  This pull will abstract any CSS that we can.  For instance, autocomplete uses what could become a fairly common UI construct.  Let's abstract this to `popover-list`.  I'm going to document the pieces here as I abstract them.   Once we get a real styleguide, we can add images for these things.

``` scss
// Any single-line "input."  These are usually present in panels that appear over the main editor
.editor.mini
```

``` scss
// A list of items that appears in a panel which has a single active selection.  Each item occupies a single row or single column in the list.
.select-list
```

``` scss
// A version of a select list which is usually smaller and appears to hover above the main editor view.  This list is usually automatically hidden when it loses focus.
.select-list.popover-list
```

``` scss
// An element which appears from the edge of Atom.  For example, go-to-line.
.overlay
.overlay.mini
```

``` scss
// An element that temporarily appears over the editor similar to OSX's notifications. 
.notification
```

/cc @probablycorey @jonrohan @kevinsawicki @nathansobo 

PS: Let me know if you'd rather not be @ mentioned on things like this.

data.title: Ui dark tweaks
data.body:
Cleans up the visual style of the command panel to match the rest of the dark theme.

data.title: Use a CSS preprocessor
data.body:
Here are a few.  We use SCSS on .com.
### [node-sass](https://github.com/andrew/node-sass)
- Allows us to use what we're using on .com.
- Everyone understands and knows this.
### [less.js](http://lesscss.org)
- Very similar syntax to SCSS. 
-  Variables and mixins use a slightly different syntax.  
- Looks like it'd be the easiest to implement since it's just a single JS file.
### [stylus](http://learnboost.github.com/stylus/)
- Built specifically for node.  
- Similar syntax as SASS.  
- The most concise syntax

/cc @jonrohan @kevinsawicki @nathansobo @probablycorey

data.title: Need better visuals for split screen
data.body:
That thick, flat gray bar used to separate editors looks out of place.  We should clean that up.

![Screen Shot 2013-02-01 at 9 37 33 AM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/25/119081/7398427a-6c96-11e2-94dc-8964b3273113.png)

/cc @jonrohan

data.title: Let's get some docs
data.body:
Over the past few day I've been working on implementing an API generation tool using [CoffeeScriptRedux](https://github.com/michaelficarra/CoffeeScriptRedux), to parse the CoffeeScript code and generate, what I prefer, "intelligent" information about code: number of methods doc'ed, recognition of project classes, JSON/AST representation, _e.t.c._. Then, last night, I discovered that [Codo](https://github.com/netzpirat/codo) does everything I wanted already. Fuck. Anyway, this thing is fucking great. Docs are written in the standard "JavaDoc/JSDoc" notation of using `@`-tags to represent information, but most everything else is interpreted from code. You can get a JSON representation of code; for methods, that looks something like this (truncated for brevity): ``` parameters: [ [Object], [Object], [Object], [Object] ], doc: { node: [Object], options: [Object], examples: [Object], params: [Object], comment: '

Run the documentation generator. This is usually done through\nthe command line utility codo that is provided by this package.

You can also run the documentation generation without writing files\nto the file system, by supplying a callback function.

', summary: 'Run the documentation generator.' }, ``` JSON representation can be used to do, for example, fuzzy-search or autocompletion. At the end of the parse, you can get something that looks like this: ``` Parsed files: 25 Classes: 21 (1 undocumented) Mixins: 4 Non-Class files: 1 Methods: 137 (0 undocumented) Constants: 3 (0 undocumented) 99.38% documented ``` This is awesome, because, like code coverage tests, docs can shoot for "90% and above" API documentation. Don't want something doc'ed? Fine, mark it as `@private` and you're off scott free. There are a few things I would want to add, such as stricter detection for types ( _i.e._ a parameter of type `Stirng` would be wrong; linking to a class/method that does not exist is wrong), but by and large codo has everything a proper API generation tool needs. Fuck docco. #### Serious stuff The difficult part for me is arranging what's actually relevant, public information; meaning, like, Coffeescript doesn't have `$` prefixes for function names, typically indicating utility or unexposed functions. Which methods are the most absolute important to get done first? On top of that, I worry about _which_ code is going to change, for example, with node-webkit bindings. So, what would be helpful for me to get started is like a basic list of "important shit." Based on class names I can probably guess the starting points: Editor, EditSession, Range--all super important. What might be good also for everyone is just to come up with [an ERD, as was done for Ace](http://ace.ajax.org/doc/template/resources/images/Ace_ERD.png).

data.title: Creating GitHub_Dark and GitHub_Light.
A better dot atom
data.body:
This provides a better .atom when you first `rake install`.  
- Copies over entire .atom/ template directory
- Creates additional folder for templates/
- Creates a default config.json file with some sane defaults [1].
- Doesn't copy over Atom -Dark and IR_Black because those are loaded by default

```
config.json
user.coffee 
user.css
packages/
   Readme.md
snippets/
   coffee.cson
themes/
   Readme.md
```

1:  Here's what the default config.json looks like:

``` json
{
  "editor": {
    "fontSize": 12
  },
  "core": {
    "themes": [
      "Atom - Dark",
      "IR_Black"
    ]
  }
}
```

I bumped the default fontSize down to 12, but I'm curious if anyone thinks it should be as large as it previously was?

Finally, I included the default Atom themes/styles.  One reason I did this was because I would end up getting Atom in a bad state while trying to add my custom editor theme since it's cascading.  Simply setting themes to `["My Theme"]` will remove all default styles.  This makes it more obvious that you're relying on built in themes by default.

data.title: Tree selection doesn't extend entire width
data.body:
Select an entry and scroll over and the selection color stops.

data.title: Write a CSON pretty printer
data.body:
We need a simple way to write CSON data and retire our current dependency on [cson](https://github.com/bevry/cson) and it's own web of dependencies. 

/cc @kevinsawicki @nathansobo

data.title: fix command panel specs that I broke
data.body:
We're now refocusing the preview list instead of the editor.

/cc @kevinsawicki

data.title: Load settings from user.coffee and user.css
data.body:
This renames `atom.coffee` to `user.coffee` and also creates a `user.css` that is loaded after all themes and packages are loaded.  `user.css` is intended for small tweaks or any style overrides you want to apply to atom.  It's a great way to make changes without the overhead of creating a theme.

/cc @nathansobo @probablycorey

data.title: Not adding a font family when the user doesn't have it set
Consider changing the binding for creating split panes
data.body: A lot of OS X apps use alt-meta-arrows to switch between tabs. On more than one occasion I've accidentally created a split pane trying to switch tabs after getting this in my fingers, and I worry this will be annoying to people with those habits. I'm not super particular on what the bindings are, but I think the current ones should go. I think Vim's `ctrl-w s` and `ctrl-w v` bindings would be good to have, but I know it's important to @defunkt to limit window manipulation bindings to a single keystroke. Ideas? What about `meta-|` and `meta--`, since it looks like you're splitting vertically / horizontally.

data.title: Adding a line-height to the editor.
Switch to next window with meta-` works, but prev window with meta-~ does not
data.body: I can easily switch to the next open Atom window using meta-` but meta-~ does not work to switch to the previous window.

data.title: Trailing fold marker geting wrapped to next line when screen is narrow
data.body:
This is throwing off rendering.

![Screen Shot 2013-01-30 at 5 46 41 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1789/113155/c7160886-6b3f-11e2-9f3c-e09b59207310.png)

/cc @kevinsawicki

data.title: Load customizations from user.css and user.coffee
data.body:
Make it easy to tweak atom styles by loading a user stylesheet `~/.atom/user.css` after everything else.  Also rename `atom.coffee` to `user.coffee` and allow the user to load custom packages and make simple functionality changes from there.  

/cc @nathansobo

data.title: Snippets aren't loading in `atom --stable`
data.body: They work in dev mode on the dev branch, but if I rake install and run `atom --stable`, no snippets. I don't feel like breaking my flow to investigate this at the moment.

data.title: Font config
data.body:
Based on issue #67. `editor.fontFamily` is now a config setting. I decided not to make `lineHeight` a config option because it feels like a theme setting more than an editor setting. 

Following @jonrohan's advice, `editor.fontSize` and `editor.fontFamily` are now stored in the html's head. Although, there may be a better way of doing this https://github.com/github/atom/blob/font-config/src/app/editor.coffee#L685

data.title: Share a single status bar among all panes?
data.body:
When I split my view horizontally, I find the duplicate status bars to be somewhat wasteful of real estate. I'm wondering if it wouldn't be better to have a single status bar at the bottom that changes its display depending on the active editor, like Sublime has. We already have the filename in the tab bar. Although this may be sad for Emacs people who like to disable the tabs.

![Screen Shot 2013-01-30 at 2 16 51 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1789/112571/63ce274e-6b22-11e2-9ad6-4d22450089ae.png)

data.title: Mini-editor loses height when displayed after changing the font size
data.body:
If you change the font size, then open something with a mini editor that was previously hidden like the command panel or fuzzy-finder, the mini editor is not the correct size.

![Screen Shot 2013-01-30 at 2 03 50 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1789/112539/d8505e7c-6b20-11e2-94b6-99762b9e68cb.png)

I think this is because we're recalculating dimensions when the font size changes without regard to whether the editor is visible or not. If the editor isn't visible, we can't calculate dimensions correctly.

data.title: Keymap.loadDirectory fails when .DS_Store is present.
data.body: I was updating my atom and atom would fail to start. Turns out we are trying to .DS_Store is being read in and causing the keymap to fail to load.

data.title: support escape key to exit command panel
data.body: escape closes most dialogs except the command panel.  This allows you to use `esc` to get out of the command panel when it's focused.

data.title: Support image viewing
data.body: It would be awesome if you could click an image in the treeview and it's rendered inside Atom.  Most editors fail miserably at this.  Sublime renders the raw image data and Atom currently just shows the file extension or type.

data.title: Editor stats
data.body:
This branch adds realtime stats about your activity to the bottom of your editor.  As you work in your editor (typing and mouse clicking) those events will be tracked and grouped on a per-minute basis and shown in the graph which is updated about every 5 seconds automagically.

Insanely big and fast GIF incoming....
![atom](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/25/111931/04af8e38-6b09-11e2-96f6-2bb155b3c679.gif)

data.title: Synchronously load active editor grammar
data.body:
All grammars are now loaded in the background which displays a flash between the editor being rendered and the grammar being available to colorize.

Load the active editor grammar up front so this doesn't happen.

data.title: Change how Atom defines a 'word'
data.body: Issued #82 caused me to rethink how Atom defines words. The config option `editor.nonWordCharacters` now determines words. I found it easier to understand and describe what is **not** a word rather than what **is** a word. This also changes Atom's word movement behavior to match Vim's instead of TextMates, because I think Vim has a better mechanic.
